properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall amounts are expected. Total snowfall: 25 to 35 cm, except 45 cm inland and over higher terrain. Time span: tonight through Monday night. Locations: Cartwright to Lodge Bay. Remarks: The heaviest snow will occur tonight and Monday morning, with snowfall rates gradually easing later Monday into Monday night. The snow may mix with rain along parts of the coast between Norman Bay and Lodge Bay on Monday afternoon. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to 60 km/h accompanying the snow will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow over some areas, mainly inland and over higher terrain where temperatures will be colder. For anyone considering travel: road closures are possible. Very heavy snowfall is expected along portions of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Please refer to warnings for adjacent areas for further details. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-07T01:06:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T09:07:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0797532698.2020
Area: Norman Bay to Lodge Bay, Cartwright to Black Tickle
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 2 to 5 millimetres of freezing precipitation are expected over parts of the Lower North Shore today. ### Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T22:39:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T09:33:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0811506916.2020
Area: Natashquan, Chevery, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional 20 to 30 cm of snow through Sunday night. A series of Pacific frontal systems will move across the region tonight and tomorrow, giving periods of snow, at times heavy. Snowfall accumulation of near 20 cm are expected for each 24 hour period that began early on Friday and will continue through the weekend. The heavy snow will ease late Monday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T03:40:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T11:41:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1452110559.2020
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain and wind is expected today and tonight. Total snowfall: 10 cm. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm. Locations: northeastern New Brunswick. Time span: today through Monday morning. Remarks: Precipitation will change to snow late this afternoon or tonight as colder air moves in. Snow will taper to flurries Monday morning. Additionally, strong northeast winds are expected tonight and Sunday along the Bay de Chaleur and Acadian coasts. A wind warning has been issued for the Acadian Peninsula. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T00:48:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T08:49:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3894407259.2020
Area: Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of weather systems will impact the North Coast Inland region (including Kitimat) with heavy rain beginning this afternoon and persist into Monday morning. During this period, rainfall amounts near 50 mm are forecast. The heavy rainfall will ease in intensity Monday morning. Due to recent significant rainfall, the ground is already near saturation and has less ability to absorb further rainfall. The upcoming period of heavy rain may bring higher than normal impacts to the region. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T04:41:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T12:42:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3380835361.2020
Area: North Coast - inland including Kitimat
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of fronts will bring upwards of 100 mm of rain across the central coast and northern Vancouver Island by Tuesday morning. While warning level rainfall criteria may not be reached, the total rainfall amount may still trigger localised flooding, debris flow or road washouts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected. A strong Pacific front will approach Haida Gwaii this morning and give rise to southeast winds up to 90 km/h. The winds are expected to shift to southwest and ease considerably in the wake of the front shortly after noon. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T23:59:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T12:37:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2369401015.2020
Area: Haida Gwaii
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will track across Eastern Quebec tonight and Sunday. For areas of the North Shore, snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimetres are expected from Baie-Comeau to Havre-Saint-Pierre, and over the western part of Anticosti Island beginning overnight through Sunday. In addition, strong winds gusting to 60 or 70 km/h accompanying this system will greatly reduce visibilities in blowing snow. Over the Southeastern Gaspé Peninsula, mixed precipitation are expected. Snowfall amounts expected are rather light, as precipitation should change over to rain early Sunday morning. In addition, there is a risk of freezing precipitation inland beginning overnight through near midday Sunday. Motorists should be prepared to deal with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-06T21:14:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T05:15:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0813664158.2020
Area: Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Anticosti
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected. A strong Pacific front will approach the central coast near midday and give rise to southeast winds up to 90 km/h. The winds are expected to ease late in the afternoon. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T01:59:03-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A disturbance tracking across the central Kivalliq will bring snow and blowing snow to most of the region later today and tonight. Snow is expected to begin along the southern coastal areas of Kivalliq this afternoon and persist into the evening hours before tapering off overnight. Total snowfall accumulations of 5 to 10 cm are expected by Monday morning with lesser amounts of 2 to 4 cm likely in the Arviat area. Along with the snow, strong southerly winds are expected to develop this afternoon gusting at times to 70 or 80 km/h. These winds combined with the falling snow will produce near blizzard conditions at times especially during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Winds are expected to diminish later this evening into the overnight hours. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T01:27:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T09:28:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3090843226.2020
Area: Arviat, Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts of 15 to 30 centimetres, strong winds and blowing snow are expected. An intense low pressure system is affecting Eastern Quebec and will bring snow at times heavy today over the Lower St. Lawrence and the Gaspé Peninsula areas. This storm will also be accompanied by strong winds gusting up to 80 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero locally over these areas. Otherwise, strong winds combined with the high tide could produce breaking sea conditions over the Northeastern coast of the Gaspé Peninsula late in the day Sunday. There is also a risk of freezing rain over the Eastern Gaspé Peninsula Sunday morning. Poor conditions will continue through Monday over the Northern Gaspé Peninsula. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T01:45:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-06T09:46:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3174089470.2020
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Rimouski Wildlife Reserve area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Trois-Pistoles area, Pohénégamook area, Kamouraska area, Rivière-du-Loup area, Témiscouata

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected over some areas. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm, except near 15 cm inland and over higher terrain. Locations: Labrador Straits. Time span: tonight. Remarks; Occasional flurries today will give way to snow, at times heavy, this evening. The snow will become mixed with rain and ice pellets near the coast before easing to showers or flurries near midnight. Snow will remain dominant inland and over higher terrain, with significant accumulations. Conditions are expected to improve over most areas by early Monday morning. For anyone considering travel beyond Red Bay: road closures are possible. Very heavy snowfall is expected along portions of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Please refer to warnings for adjacent areas for further details. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions will develop tonight as an upper warm front brings snow in concert with a very strong easterly surface wind. Easterly winds of 80 km/h gusting to 100 near the Richardson Mountains will generate near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow beginning this evening. Blizzard conditions will end Monday morning as the winds ease. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. An intense frontal system is developing and rapidly approaching the BC Coast. Rain, heavy at times, will develop later this evening over west Vancouver Island. Total rainfall accumulation of 120 to 150 mm is expected. The heavy rain will ease Monday evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A series of weather systems will impact the Central Coast Inland region (including Bella Coola) with heavy rain beginning this afternoon and persist into Monday morning. During this period, rainfall amounts near 50 mm are forecast. The heavy rainfall will ease in intensity Monday morning. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog patches will continue early this morning before dissipating late this morning. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. The ground, already near saturation, has little ability to absorb further rainfall. Additional rainfall: 5 to 10 mm. Locations: southern New Brunswick. Time span: Tapering off throughout the day today. Remarks: Rainfall amounts may be lower than the standard criteria for a rainfall warning; however, the saturated ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Significant pooling and runoff are likely to occur. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T00:46:02-00:00

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 130 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Time span: strengthening early this morning and diminishing early this afternoon. ### Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds.
